reviews.text: Babylon’s Fall is a surprisingly dull affair, with repetitive gameplay, a bland story, and multiplayer where things are just too easy to provide any real challenge.

The way these systems are set out is really odd too. Even after clearing two cloisters you still cannot do the most basic of things in the game, which is visiting the blacksmith to enhance your weapons or get rid of gear you just do not need.
The artwork and graphics are incredibly dated
The combat at the game's core is so simple and lacking in challenge, especially if you have a full team.
The most engaging part of the game is experimenting with different weapons early on, with some having different effects like enhancing attacks or providing healing when being used.
The hub world does not really provide much outside of being the place you go back to start a new quest, or to redeem rewards for completing in-game achievements.
The music is forgettable and the story is just really dull
Babylon’s Fall doesn’t scale enemy difficulty based on party size, making co-op feel too easy
You will come to appreciate the power of ranged attacks
The artwork and graphics are incredibly dated
Every dungeon follows the same basic pattern of going through three or four mob battles before fighting some kind of boss
The camera might suddenly end up behind a piece of the environment
The live service model is pointless
The combat is dull, the story bland, and it is just forgettable
The armour does similar but it all looks a bit ugly, so it’s best to use a skin that hides what the armour look like.
There's a demo to try Babylon’s Fall may teach you the value of money, and what not to waste it on
Even if Babylon’s Fall was a free-to-play game I still wouldn’t spend my time on it. I do wonder what’s happened during its development for this to be the result.
